items.title:
First, the good part of the Anthropic ads: they are funny, and I laughed.

But I wonder why Anthropi...
items.content:
First, the good part of the Anthropic ads: they are funny, and I laughed.

But I wonder why Anthropic would go for something so clearly dishonest. Our most important principle for ads says that we won‚Äôt do exactly this; we would obviously never run ads in the way Anthropic depicts them. We are not stupid and we know our users would reject that.

I guess it‚Äôs on brand for Anthropic doublespeak to use a deceptive ad to critique theoretical deceptive ads that aren‚Äôt real, but a Super Bowl ad is not where I would expect it.

More importantly, we believe everyone deserves to use AI and are committed to free access, because we believe access creates agency. More Texans use ChatGPT for free than total people use Claude in the US, so we have a differently-shaped problem than they do. (If you want to pay for ChatGPT Plus or Pro, we don't show you ads.)

Anthropic serves an expensive product to rich people. We are glad they do that and we are doing that too, but we also feel strongly that we need to bring AI to billions of people who can‚Äôt pay for subscriptions.

Maybe even more importantly: Anthropic wants to control what people do with AI‚Äîthey block companies they don't like from using their coding product (including us), they want to write the rules themselves for what people can and can't use AI for, and now they also want to tell other companies what their business models can be.

We are committed to broad, democratic decision making in addition to access. We are also committed to building the most resilient ecosystem for advanced AI. We care a great deal about safe, broadly beneficial AGI, and we know the only way to get there is to work with the world to prepare.

One authoritarian company won't get us there on their own, to say nothing of the other obvious risks. It is a dark path.

As for our Super Bowl ad: it‚Äôs about builders, and how anyone can now build anything.

We are enjoying watching so many people switch to Codex. There have now been 500,000 app downloads since launch on Monday, and we think builders are really going to love what‚Äôs coming in the next few weeks. I believe Codex is going to win.

We will continue to work hard to make even more intelligence available for lower and lower prices to our users.

This time belongs to the builders, not the people who want to control them.

items.title:
A lot of people quote tweeted this as 1 year anniversary of vibe coding. Some retrospective -

I've ...
items.content:
A lot of people quote tweeted this as 1 year anniversary of vibe coding. Some retrospective -

I've had a Twitter account for 17 years now (omg) and I still can't predict my tweet engagement basically at all. This was a shower of thoughts throwaway tweet that I just fired off without thinking but somehow it minted a fitting name at the right moment for something that a lot of people were feeling at the same time, so here we are: vibe coding is now mentioned on my Wikipedia as a major memetic "contribution" and even its article is longer. lol

The one thing I'd add is that at the time, LLM capability was low enough that you'd mostly use vibe coding for fun throwaway projects, demos and explorations. It was good fun and it almost worked. Today (1 year later), programming via LLM agents is increasingly becoming a default workflow for professionals, except with more oversight and scrutiny. The goal is to claim the leverage from the use of agents but without any compromise on the quality of the software. Many people have tried to come up with a better name for this to differentiate it from vibe coding, personally my current favorite "agentic engineering":

- "agentic" because the new default is that you are not writing the code directly 99% of the time, you are orchestrating agents who do and acting as oversight.
- "engineering" to emphasize that there is an art & science and expertise to it. It's something you can learn and become better at, with its own depth of a different kind.

In 2026, we're likely to see continued improvements on both the model layer and the new agent layer. I feel excited about the product of the two and another year of progress.

üöÄüöÄüöÄ vLLM on NVIDIA GB200: 26.2K prefill TPGS, 10.1K decode TPGS for DeepSeek R1/V3.
üìà 3-5x throughput vs H200 - with half the GPUs!

Key optimizations:
- NVFP4 GEMM for MoE experts
- FP8 GEMM for MLA
- Kernel fusion (RoPE+Quant+Q Write)
- Weight offloading v2 with async prefetch

Thanks to the @AIatMeta and @NVIDIAAIDev teams for the collaboration! üôè

items.title:
Very excited to release Voxtral 2!

Voxtral 2 comes with two powerful new models:

Voxtral Realtime:...
items.content:
Very excited to release Voxtral 2!

Voxtral 2 comes with two powerful new models:

Voxtral Realtime: a SOTA real-time transcription model released under an Apache 2 license, with latency configurable to sub-200 ms

Voxtral Mini Transcribe 2: a SOTA transcription model with speaker diarization, word-level timestamps, and context biasing

Voxtral 2 supports 13 languages. It‚Äôs available on the Mistral API and is one of the most cost-effective transcription APIs on the market.

Yes, it would be some kind of a ‚Äúgeneral‚Äù intelligence.

But to my tastes, if an AI is failing at tr...
items.content:
Yes, it would be some kind of a ‚Äúgeneral‚Äù intelligence.

But to my tastes, if an AI is failing at trivial things, it falls short of AGI.  I think that most people, once they observe it making mistakes that they would never make, wouldn‚Äôt be fully convinced of its capabilities.
items.author: @ShaneLegg
items.summary: Shane Legg argues that if AI fails at trivial tasks humans wouldn't fail at, it shouldn't be considered AGI - regardless of general capabilities. People won't be convinced of AGI if they observe obvious mistakes.
items.reasoning: Important definitional contribution from AGI pioneer. Provides clear criterion for evaluating AGI claims that differs from current hype.

But to my tastes, if an AI is failing at trivial things, it falls short of AGI. I think that most people, once they observe it making mistakes that they would never make, wouldn‚Äôt be fully convinced of its capabilities.

items.title:
Every day, I am blowing my mind with Claude Code.

With Google Workspace MCP, skills, and concise te...
items.content:
Every day, I am blowing my mind with Claude Code.

With Google Workspace MCP, skills, and concise team directory in my Claude md file, I can type the following:

/ss 5 for /mtg with alyssa then /debrief 30 walmart with elliot 

And to translate that command into actual human language... Claude goes into a specific screenshots folder, grabs the 5 most recent screenshots as context, uses the content in them to set up with a meeting with Alyssa (based on timezones including travel references in calendars and avails, sends her invite), then after that, automatically queued up, sets up a 30min meeting with elliot and invites him and includes a full debrief on walmart including emails with and about walmart, slack messages about walmart, news about walmart, and next steps that are *specifically written* to align to our 2026 business goals (because embedded in the debrief task is an action to retrieve my 414-line Open Machine context document and use that as context to write).

And some people still haven't tried it.
items.author: @alliekmiller
items.summary: Allie Miller detailed showcase of Claude Code with Google Workspace MCP - complex workflow automation including meeting scheduling, context retrieval, debrief generation aligned to business goals
items.reasoning: Highly detailed practical AI workflow from credible AI professional, demonstrates sophisticated MCP integration and custom command chaining, very high engagement (24K views), inspires practical adoption
items.summary_html: Allie Miller detailed showcase of Claude Code with Google Workspace MCP - complex workflow automation including meeting scheduling, context retrieval, debrief generation aligned to business goals
items.content_html:
Every day, I am blowing my mind with Claude Code.

With Google Workspace MCP, skills, and concise team directory in my Claude md file, I can type the following:

/ss 5 for /mtg with alyssa then /debrief 30 walmart with elliot

And to translate that command into actual human language... Claude goes into a specific screenshots folder, grabs the 5 most recent screenshots as context, uses the content in them to set up with a meeting with Alyssa (based on timezones including travel references in calendars and avails, sends her invite), then after that, automatically queued up, sets up a 30min meeting with elliot and invites him and includes a full debrief on walmart including emails with and about walmart, slack messages about walmart, news about walmart, and next steps that are *specifically written* to align to our 2026 business goals (because embedded in the debrief task is an action to retrieve my 414-line Open Machine context document and use that as context to write).

And some people still haven't tried it.

items.title: Most companies will laugh you out of the room if you try to replace people with an unsupervised AI p...
items.content:
Most companies will laugh you out of the room if you try to replace people with an unsupervised AI process.

AI + Humans > AI alone.
Every day of the week and twice on weekends.

Go out and talk to these companies: There are so many use cases you can't solve with AI alone.

The trick is to create a process that gives people control.

Something as simple as an approval step before an agent takes action, and many use cases will become doable.

Take a research agent as an example.

Here is what the agent does:

‚Ä¢ Looks into AI topics
‚Ä¢ Sends a summary of ideas to Slack
‚Ä¢ Waits for the user to approve those ideas
‚Ä¢ Writes the approved notes directly into Google Docs

Without the approval gate, the agent will litter the document with garbage. It would go off in random directions, and people would spend more time fixing its output than it would've taken them to do the work themselves.

With the gate, the user approves a direction, and the agent will execute it cleanly.

This pattern works everywhere:

‚Ä¢ Sales reviews leads before they hit HubSpot
‚Ä¢ Finance signs off before invoices get processed
‚Ä¢ DevOps confirms before a deploy runs
‚Ä¢ Legal checks before a contract is filled

items.title: My honest opinion: people who claim to have easily "one shotted" something with AI probably work on ...
items.content: My honest opinion: people who claim to have easily "one shotted" something with AI probably work on *very* conventional use cases. Or have ready made templates of steps that need to be accomplished. Every single project I've worked at with AI has resulted in lots of back and forth screaming at the terminal to redo something in a very significant way.

items.summary: Tunguz argues that people claiming to 'one-shot' things with AI likely work on conventional use cases or have pre-made templates, noting real AI projects involve extensive back-and-forth iteration

items.title: I talked with the guy behind @higgsfield_ai 's influencer network last week. (I won't name him becau...
items.content:
I talked with the guy behind @higgsfield_ai 's influencer network last week. (I won't name him because it wasn't an interview, just a business call, in part because I wanted to get to know him since he so dominates my feed).

This is a company that has millions of users. Is not yet a year old. 

And is run by a social media strategist who is running the world's largest influencer network. Er, a marketing strategist. One of the most diabolical I've known, and most genius. I told him I bet he gives a @sxsw keynote soon. And he knows it! Says he is sorry, but to be interesting he has to be pushing the lines.

When a pattern works so well everyone copies it (and I'm getting offers from many) maybe sit back and learn "why did that work?"

This is a company that is not even a year old and we all know its name. And now we know everyone who mentions Higgsfield is paid. 

Except I haven't been and have mentioned it many times. But that is changing.

I need some of that money, my wife was laid off last year and my income isn't high enough. And it is one of the rare ones that pay people like me. I disclose all of those in my newsletter, which is really what they are buying, since that's what I'm selling.

But I'll be honest, I try out companies that pay me and give them lots of feedback for their dollar. I'm one of the best in the world at doing that. 

But I get the whole "this is an awful company" argument. I see the mistakes of someone hustling too hard, reminded of the guy who pitched me at Techcrunch Disrupt in the bathroom. 

And crossing too many ethical lines. But then Trump is President. So it's hard for me to know where the lines are anymore. I find myself listening to people lately who have the lines all figured out more since I've found this world difficult to navigate.

This guy is trying to capture attention in a world where none of us have any. 

Don't ask me, I'm a guy famous for wearing a Google Glass in the shower.

This post, I know, will get me lots of hate. Unfollows. Blocks. 

But that is OK, I'd rather be hanging out with a small crowd of smart people than a large crowd of the masses.

I built an entire list, called AI Influencers, just because of this company taking over my feed. For a year old startup there are many lessons here to be learned. Some good, some bad. 

Hell, wait until you hear that the startup I left Microsoft for ended up closing within years. We burned through almost $10 million. Back when that was like getting a billion today. 

I think losing relevance, and your business, that way, is worse than being an asshole company. I know quite a few asshole companies. The list is long.

Add another on. 

I was not compensated for this post. Nor did I collude with anyone else on it.

Login, first install Tailscale on VPS and laptop

Once it works add the Tailscale subnet (google the address) to Hetzner inbound firewall SSH port, don't add any more inbound ports

Then play with it

items.title:
We are all obsolete so need to learn something new.

Like how to better wield the super powers we ju...
items.content:
We are all obsolete so need to learn something new.

Like how to better wield the super powers we just all were given.

I guarantee Aditya will write better prompts to build software than I can.

The experts have a better vocabulary than non experts.

Who do you want debugging your system?

Me or a computer scientist?

In my defense I did report more bugs in Adobe Acrobat 1.0 than any other human. Won a nice printer for that honor.

That said the computer scientist will beat me 99 times out of 100. 

The one they miss is my job. Strategy. Why I told Bill Gates to buy all of Web 2.0.

He didn‚Äôt listen. I have nightmares about what would have happened if he did.

Just got my friend home from his knee surgery. Things are good. Dreaming of a world where we can walk more than 100 feet. You never realize what you got until you suffer with a friend who can‚Äôt walk.

If you are obsolete start a business.

The fastest way to learn to do something new.

items.title: One guy, at Unity, @3duaun took many risks by talking with me every week, sometimes more often, for ...
items.content:
One guy, at Unity, @3duaun took many risks by talking with me every week, sometimes more often, for years here on X. In public, without recording his space.

We talked about this world coming and what it means to human consciousness.

Discussed consciousness with many. All led me to the conclusion that literally no one understands anything about their own brain and how it works.

Everyone will need to know a lot more before brain/computer interfaces arrive.

Otherwise they can control you. 

Worse they can control your kids, or grandkids, someday. 

Learn about cognitive sovereignty in a brain computer interface world and what regulations we will need. 

Click the Grok button and ask. 

And nice to see world models shoving directly into @unity here.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Extensive post on cognitive sovereignty, brain-computer interfaces, and need for regulations before BCIs arrive to prevent manipulation
items.reasoning: Substantive discussion of important long-term AI ethics concern from experienced tech commentator, high engagement (6.6k views)

items.title:
So many people are shipping AI-generated code without even looking at it.

It's terrifying!

AI mode...
items.content:
So many people are shipping AI-generated code without even looking at it.

It's terrifying!

AI models are improving, but they still make a ton of mistakes.

Now more than ever, you get code that looks fine and passes a quick glance, but underneath, it doesn't work: race conditions, broken contracts, duplicated logic, and any number of subtle issues that aren't obvious.

This will come back to haunt us forever.

The team behind Qodo just launched their 2.0 version to address this.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago Pino warns about the dangers of developers shipping AI-generated code without review, citing issues like race conditions, broken contracts, and duplicated logic that pass quick visual inspection.
items.reasoning: Important topic about AI code quality and safety that resonates with the community. High engagement (83 likes, 10K views). Leads into product promotion but raises valid industry concern about vibe-coding risks.

Had @blevlabs create this report by looking at my Security list here on X. 

Done on request from @realAlanHoward. 

Every day I'll do a different report from a community here on X.

items.title: To get really really good at anything most of the time you need to endure many months, or even years...
items.content:
To get really really good at anything most of the time you need to endure many months, or even years, of being pretty bad at it. 

Unfortunately no job tolerates that sort of prolonged underperformance. 

Which is why at most jobs the most rational MO is to stick to things that you are OK at. 

Which is why mediocrity is so prevalent in professional world.
items.author: @tunguz

items.title:
@blevlabs @InsiderPresider @realAlanHoward Here's the prompt:

We'd like to make an AI security repo...
items.content:
@blevlabs @InsiderPresider @realAlanHoward Here's the prompt:

We'd like to make an AI security report.

Grab 5,000 new posts from this list: https://t.co/ZMK3vj4UPO

Then analyze the posts for anything that refers to AI security. Then write a report with that analysis.

Look for anything that degrades trust of a system. Malicious attacks. Exploits. Vulnerabilities. Poor security design. Privacy holes. Attack vectors. Particularly when it comes to AI systems, or LLMs.

Present the top 20 security problems that are being discussed right now. And whatever analysis you think people need to know to protect themselves and their corporate systems.

+++++++++++

It ran one report, then gave it another prompt:

Wow, this is genuinely excellent, and a lot more substantial than I was expecting. The structure and sourcing make it easy to follow, and the focus on agent-level risk aligns with some of my own concerns in this space.

From my side, what would take it to the next level is a light executive lens on each item that separates technical severity from real-world organisational risk, and calls out where controls look good on paper but are hard to land in practice due to incentives, cost, or governance gaps.

Can you rerun the report given this feedback? (Don't get new posts from X API, just use the data you already have).
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer sharing full prompt used to generate AI security report from Twitter/X data
items.reasoning: Useful prompt engineering example showing multi-step AI workflow for security analysis, practical methodology revealed
items.summary_html: Scobleizer sharing full prompt used to generate AI security report from Twitter/X data

From my side, what would take it to the next level is a light executive lens on each item that separates technical severity from real-world organisational risk, and calls out where controls look good on paper but are hard to land in practice due to incentives, cost, or governance gaps.

items.title:
Here is a recommendation for you:

Do not install a tool that will overwhelm you with nitpicks and d...
items.content:
Here is a recommendation for you:

Do not install a tool that will overwhelm you with nitpicks and details about your code that don't matter.

You'll end up ignoring everything.

You want something that surfaces critical issues.

Qodo 2.0's new agentic PR review achieves the highest precision and recall in issue finding.

That means

1. More real, critical issues will show up for you
2. Fewer non-issues (or trivial things) will sneak in

Here's how it works:

1. They have multiple specialized agents running in parallel and reasoning about your code from different angles.

2. They use your full codebase as the context for these agents (not just diffs). This means the agents understand your code's architecture.

3. The agents learn from your PR history and your team's patterns.

That last one is the key.

The system adapts to how your team actually works instead of applying generic rules.

You can try this out here: https://t.co/mUb7pLJ6Ui

Thanks to the Qodo team for partnering with me on this post.

items.title: Every time I call my bank, I have to spend 5 minutes going through the most useless phone tree ever....
items.content:
Every time I call my bank, I have to spend 5 minutes going through the most useless phone tree ever.

They force me to listen to ads about their products, and I've never solved my problem without speaking to somebody.

I can't wait for these useless phone trees to die. We already have the tech, so I guess it's a matter of time.

‚Üí Weeks of production

items.content:
For years, content creation looked like this ‚Üí

‚Üí Photoshoots
‚Üí Agencies
‚Üí Weeks of production
‚Üí One final asset

Now the input is radically smaller.

‚Üí One product image
‚Üí Or a single webpage

And the output explodes into motion videos, lifestyle visuals, even virtual try-ons.

Static assets are becoming content engines.

items.title: Most benchmarks test isolated skills like fact retrieval or trivia. But real research requires synth...
items.content:
Most benchmarks test isolated skills like fact retrieval or trivia. But real research requires synthesis across many sources, nuanced analysis, and accurate sources.

DRACO includes 100 tasks across 10 domains‚ÄîAcademic, Finance, Law, Medicine, Technology, General Knowledge, UX Design, Personal Assistant, Shopping, and Needle in a Haystack‚Äîeach evaluated against ~40 expert-defined criteria.

üáßüá∑ To show you more I made a tour of a Brazilian buffet during lunch

This is one of my favorite ones

Enshittification has NOT hit here and hopefully never will

Every day there is a different theme for the food like European, Asian, Brazilian etc

Again it's mostly whole foods, and you can do meat and vegetables really well here

The lemonade is also good (ask without sugar) very acid!!!! üçã‚Äçüü©

items.title:
The evidence for anti depressants (SSRI) continues to weaken

Increasingly research shows physical e...
items.content:
The evidence for anti depressants (SSRI) continues to weaken

Increasingly research shows physical exercise and whole foods are more effective at treating depression than any medication

But of course if you go on anti depressants it does feel like they "work", right?

"Work" as in you will feel great for a bit, then the side effects hit:
- Low libido
- Sexual dysfunction (no pp hard)
- Ejaculation issues
- Nausea
- Diarhea
- Constipation
- Tremors
- Insomnia
- Drowsiness
- Weight gain
- Headaches
- Dry mouth
- Increased sweating

Once you realize that you made a mistake it's too late

You're now physically dependent on them and it's not easy to get off them

This shit is contagious

items.title: Hetzner (and most VPS hosts) automatically disable password login if you add an SSH key during creat...
items.content:
Hetzner (and most VPS hosts) automatically disable password login if you add an SSH key during creating the server (usually on their web dashboards)

You should never have password login ever because it can be brute forced (they try 1000s of passwords)

So yes:
- Tailscale firewall subnet for SSH
- Cloudflare firewall subnet for HTTPS (web server)
- disable passwordless login
- enable unattended upgrades and auto reboots (for security updates etc)

My personal one that's fun:
- set the SSH port to some obscure number (I like security by obscurity)

You can install Claude Code and just ask to do all these things

items.title:
You should never ever expose a VPS to the entire internet

Always firewall it to subnets

If you hos...
items.content:
You should never ever expose a VPS to the entire internet

Always firewall it to subnets

If you host a website you should only allow port 443 (HTTPS) inbound from Cloudflare's IP range / subnets

Port 22 (SSH) only from your Tailscale subnet range

That means you create a "tunnel" from Cloudflare and Tailscale (your laptop) to your server's door

You still need your SSH key to open the door btw

If you don't, ANYONE in the entire world can connect to your VPS and if there's just one security vulnerability and you didn't upgrade your VPS you can get hacked

If you do have it firewalled with Tailscale subnet only, it means only if they hack your laptop they could get in via your Tailscale there

Another thing is ask OpenClaw or Claude Code to enable unattended upgrades with auto reboot

items.content:
@robj3d3 Go to https://t.co/m3W9BqaPoS

Set up a $2.50/mo VPS

Add SSH key when creating

Login, first install Tailscale on VPS and laptop

Once it works add the Tailscale subnet (google the address) to Hetzner inbound firewall SSH port, don't add any more inbound ports

Now only u can SSH into it, safe

Then install OpenClaw on the VPS via SSH

Don't connect any of your accounts, make a Telegram bot and add that

Then play with it!

items.title:
This report from the @CatoInstitute is worth reading.

They separately evaluate the effects of all i...
items.content:
This report from the @CatoInstitute is worth reading.

They separately evaluate the effects of all immigrants, low-skill immigrants and illegal immigrants.

In each case, the fiscal effect is *beneficial*.

There are reasons for limiting immigration and making sure its legal.  

But contrary to common claims, the budget is not one of them.

items.title: @Twelvisten @higgsfield_ai I agree. This is a rough and tumble neighborhood. Apple ripped off a good...
items.content:
@Twelvisten @higgsfield_ai I agree. This is a rough and tumble neighborhood. Apple ripped off a good friend. He might eventually get paid. It happens even in the best companies, is my point. It shouldn't, but it does. 

Also, when I worked at Microsoft I learned very quickly that what is in public is rarely the full story. And I know none of it personally until today.

Also, when I worked at Microsoft I learned very quickly that what is in public is rarely the full story. And I know none of it personally until today.
